awd_titl_txt: Population consequences of sexually dimorphic responses in a plant species to ongoing and experimental changes in climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Predicting how a population of organisms will respond to changes in the climate they experience requires understanding how small-scale changes in ecological processes translate to patterns at broad scales. Most studies of biological responses to environmental change have either documented the natural pattern of whole-species response to past change or, alternatively, the effects of experimentally manipulated environment on the performance of a few individuals. The former approach benefits from its realism, but is too coarse to elucidate the physiological responses underlying the response to changes in climate. The latter approach demonstrates these mechanisms in detail, but does so at small spatial scales and under artificially simplified experimental conditions. This study seeks to bridge these two approaches, studying the responses of the plant Valeriana edulis to climatic variation at field sites in the Colorado Rockies. Individuals of this species have separate sexes (i.e. are either male or female) and the sexes respond differently to changes in climate.  The researchers will investigate how these variable, individual-level responses to climate scale up to determine population dynamics and species persistence. This work will be conducted at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL) using historic and contemporary demographic data to compare the effects of a changing climate over space (an 1800 m elevational gradient), between experimental manipulations (warming and snow removal), and over time (40 year record).  This study also provides opportunities for education and outreach through undergraduate and graduate scientific training, citizen science initiatives, and through the development of web-based curricula in collaboration with the RMBL.

This research asks whether the sex-mediated physiological response of males and females in dioecious species to changes in climate can skew population structure (sex ratios) with resultant demographic consequences. The researchers will construct size- and sex-structured demographic models using historic and contemporary data on vital rates, mating functions, water use efficiency and primary (seed) sex ratio for populations under (1) historic climate, (2) contemporary climate over the species' elevation range, and (3) experimental warming and snow removal. Using model selection and life table response experiment analyses, this study assesses the overall consequences of spatial (1800 m elevation), temporal (past vs. present) and manipulated (present vs. simulated future) variation in climate for population performance, as well as the specific contribution of (and physiological basis to) climate-skewed sex ratios.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting how biological systems will respond to climate change requires understanding how small-scale changes in ecological processes translate to ecological patterns at broad scales. Most studies of biological responses to climate change taken one of two approaches.  First, past studies have documented the natural pattern of whole-species response to past change, focusing on how species ranges have shifted.  Second, past studies have studied the effects of experimentally manipulated climate on the physiology and performance of a few individuals. The former approach benefits from its realism but is too coarse to elucidate the climatic factors or physiological responses underlying the response to climate change. The later approach demonstrates these mechanisms in detail but does so at small spatial scales and under artificially simplified experimental conditions.

 

This study bridged these two approaches, studying the responses of the plant Valeriana edulis to climatic variation at field sites in the Colorado Rockies. The researchers used this to understand how these variable, individual-level responses to climate scale up to determine population dynamics and species persistence. This work was conducted at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL) using historic and contemporary demographic data to compare the effects of climate change over space (an 1800 m elevational gradient), among experimental manipulations (warming and snow removal) and over time (40 years of climate change). This study thus provided unique mechanistic insight into the linkages between individual variation in response to climatic change and population-level response to climate change. 

 

Valeriana edulis is dioecious, meaning that individual plants are either male, producing pollen alone, or female producing ovules alone (and, if pollinated, seeds). This study asked whether the sex-specific physiological response to climate change of males and females can skew population sex ratios (the relative abundance of males and females), and the resultant demographic consequences of such skewed sex ratios. The researchers conducted construct size- and sex-structured demographic models using historic and contemporary data on vital rates (growth, reproduction, survival), mating functions (how pollen availability affects seed production), and water use efficiency under (1) historic climate, (2) contemporary climate over the species' elevation range, and (3) experimental warming and snow removal. Using model selection and life table response experiment analyses, this study assessed the overall consequences of spatial (1800 m elevation), temporal (past vs. present) and manipulated (present vs. simulated future) variation in climate for population performance, as well as the specific contribution of (and physiological basis to) climate-skewed sex ratios.

 

This study made three key findings.  First, this study revealed that Valeriana edulis males and females differ in ecologically important traits, including traits such as water use efficiency that mediates the acquisition and allocation of resources, altering individual interactions with the environment. Second, this study documented sex-specific responses to climate change over the past four decades and across its 1800-meter elevation range. Increased elevation was associated with increased water availability and female frequency, likely owing to sex-specific water use efficiency and survival. As a result, sex ratios were strongly female biased at the highest elevations.  Warming over the past four decades caused male frequency to increase across the species' elevational distribution, thus shifting the population sex ratios previously observed at lower elevations to higher elevations.  As a result, population sex ratio moved upslope at 175 meters per decade, a rate of trait shift outpacing the range shifts reported for most species by an order of magnitude. This increase in male frequency with elevation and over time reduced pollen limitation and increased seed production. And third, this study demonstrated that the consequences of experimentally manipulated climate change paralleled those show to occur across the elevational gradient and over four decades of climate change.  Advancing the timing of snowmelt by ~ 14 days and warming plants by ~ 3o C for 5 years improved male performance relative to females, and demographic models demonstrated that this these effects would ultimately reduce skewed population sex ratios and increase seed set.

 

Overall, these results underscore the importance of ecological differences between the sexes in mediating biological responses to climate change. This study also provided significant broader impacts.  Two graduate students, six field assistants, and 10 undergraduate students received training through their participation in this work. This study also provided significant opportunities for outreach on the science of climate change through undergraduate and graduate scientific training, and citizen science initiatives in collaboration with the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory. Finally, this work provided significant benefit to the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory by facilitating the PI's participation in service and governance as a member of the Board of Trustees.
